title: Metropolitan Line suspended after mum gives birth on train
text:
Arrivals board

Every year 1.3 billion people use the tube and many of them are used to hearing excuses as to why their train has been delayed.

Today, in what is a surprisingly rare occurrence given the number of passengers who use the network, the Metropolitan Line was brought to a standstill because a baby was born at Baker Street Station.

TFL alerted passengers on its service information notice, although clearly this should be renamed ‘arrivals board’.

The board read: ‘Eastbound Metropolitan Line service is suspended owning to a customer giving birth on a train at Baker Street.’

Given there had only been four recorded incidents of ‘tube babies’ in the underground’s long history – it opened on January 10, 1863 – amazingly this is the second birth on the network this year.

We'd like to wish a huge congratulations to the mum and her new baby, born today at #WarrenStreet We didn't get there in time to deliver baby, but we still love a #goodnews story 😊👶🏼 pic.twitter.com/MXdB8f2z5t — BTP NetworkResponse (@BTPNetworkResp) January 15, 2019

Today’s news came after a new mum gave birth to a baby boy at Warren Street in January.

On that day medical student Hamzah Selim, who was on his way home from an anatomy lecture, helped with the delivery after hearing a woman screaming.

Before that, in 2009, the first ever boy was born on the tube when 32-year-old Michelle Jenkins, of Barking, went into labour while travelling on the Jubilee Line.

Staff at London Bridge Station called an ambulance but Ms Jenkins gave birth in the staff room before it arrived.

And in December 2008, Julia Kowalska became the second person to give birth on the underground when baby Jennifer arrived.

There does seem to be an oddly long gap between births as it appears you need to go back to May 13, 1924, for the next, and first.

Picture of the first woman to give birth on the London Underground (Picture: British Newspaper Archive)

Marie Cordery, according to the Uxbridge & West Drayton Gazette, had a bit of a rollercoaster entry into the world.

Her mother Daisy Britannia Kate Hammond of Wealdstone was on her way to hospital on the Bakerloo line when she ‘became ill at Marylebone’.

Passengers were cleared from the train, which then sped along the lines to a dead-end tunnel at Elephant and Castle where an ambulance was waiting to take her and the baby to Lambeth Infirmary.

Their departure was watched by a crowd of well-wishers.

Transport for London has been contacted to get further clarification on the numbers of births on the network.

Metropolitan Line commuters were in good spirits about the latest passenger to join their ranks.
